positive.review: Deep Rock Galactic has quickly become one of my favorite co-op games. My friend and I can sink hours into it without even noticing the time pass. The visual style is striking and instantly recognizable, and the charactersâ€™ voice lines add a ton of charm and personality to every mission. The teamwork, the hectic fights and the sense of progression all come together perfectly. Honestly, itâ€™s one of the best cooperative experiences you can play right now. Rock and stone!

This is the most polished, feature-complete co-op shooter I have played. It stands above Left 4 Dead, Payday 2's golden era, and Space Marine 2 for me. These devs do not disappoint, and I have gone out of my way to buy every bonus cosmetic pack they release for the game, just to support them further.

The game starts out a little slow with the progression, as that is how it teaches you all of the different mechanics of your weapons and gear. However, the longer you play, the more the game offers to you, and that progression goes on for a surprisingly long time.

ROCK AND STONE!

Possibly the most fun co-op game out there and it just keeps on giving.

Every class plays very distinctive roles while still being able to cover for eachother; no one class is necessary. To add to this there are many wacky loadouts that can completely change your playstyle.

Cooperation is important but I've rarely found myself stressing over incompetent teammates as you can almost always just pull your own weight, this is the core of what makes this game so fun, cooperation feels great but so does doing things by yourself.

The game's humor is also top notch and I love how there is a ton of little semi hidden interactables with funny voice lines, even after 300 hours I'm still finding things.

The gameplay loop consists of trying to obtain weapons mods and cosmetics, there aren't a ton of different mission types but coupling with biomes, the random terrain and the various modifiers and curve balls the game throws at you, at 300 hours it still feels far off from getting old.

Voted this in for the labor of love!

With 800ish hours, I'm still exploring all the game space around the overclocks and grinding out deeper promotions, and I'm looking forward to fresh content early next year! It just keeps on giving. Amazing game, best coop experience.

Got gifted this game during Season 3, but i haven't really gotten into it until Season 4 rolled around. I missed out on a lot.

The game is simply good. The majority of players you encounter in the lobbies are really chill and usually have no problem with you messing something up. The gameplay loop is nice, there's no huge penalties for losing the mission, the only paid content is the game itself and the DLC armors and skins, which are purely cosmetic. 

The seasons have their own "season pass," which is free as well. AND, as of Season 5, you can simply go back to replay the old seasons if you haven't finished some or never played them. This also helped the developers to put the cosmetics from their perspective seasons back into these said seasons, thus lessening the loot bloat in the "cargo crates," "lost packs" and "core infusers" And as for loot, you never get double of the thing you already own (unless its a beard or a weapon skin for a separate class), which means that you're closer to getting what you want every time.

The game is primarily co-op, but it also lets you to play "solo" with a drone that follows you, shoots bugs and mines minerals that you point towards to. You can always disable the drone for the true solo experience if you're brave enough.

The developers, Ghost Ship Games, also deserve huge praise. Actually listening to the community and often interacting with them is such a welcome change in the sea of triple A bullcrap. They're nice people.

Cannot recommend this game enough. Once you get into the groove of things, it's real fun.

This design allows for an incredible synergy between the 4 classes, with their tools and equipment greatly complimenting one-another. In addition to all this, Deep Rock Galactic gets new free content regularly via a seasonal model, as well as a paid cosmetic bundle for each season which they don't try and excessively push onto players. I cant recommend getting into deep rock enough, The community are amazing and there's no shortage of other dwarves to help you learn. Rock and Stone.

Sometimes beginners get confused about the concept of the game. No, it's not minecraft with guns in space, it's more like Left 4 dead in caves in space. The gameplay concept can be described as follows: you go to a randomly generated cave, a level where you must complete the task assigned to you and successfully evacuate back to the station. The gameplay itself is divided into 2 large components: the puzzle part and the shooter part.

The puzzle part is all that you will do in moments of silence. Moving underground alone is difficult and dangerous, and therefore each class has a unique set of tools to speed up the crossing of the terrain. The faster you get all the necessary minerals, the lower the chance that you will become bug food. The shooter part begins at the same moment when you hear the scream of dozens of beetles and the menacing stomp of larger beetles. The most common opponent for you will be an ordinary glyphid warrior, and if they don't look formidable on lower difficulties, then on high difficulties the continuous stream of arachnids will be the main reason why you can't stop shooting.

The atmosphere of the game is the strongest part of the game. Narrow tunnels where you can be taken by surprise, and giant caves, against which you yourself are like an ant, are perfectly complemented by a suitable soundtrack. The feeling of darkness and isolation will always go with you.

Let's talk about classes in more detail: there are 4 classes in the game, which you can switch between at any time. Unlike many co-op games, DRG does not have pronounced "carry" and "support" classes, everyone has something that others do not have. If you don't have enough of any of the 4 classes, you will always feel its absence, and your thoughts will flash: "If only we had a driller!"

Driller is the main area damage provider in the team, possessing a flamethrower and explosive packs, but having serious problems killing large and/or distant targets. To overcome caves, it is equipped with drills that can level the landscape, make ladders in the rock both up and down, drill straight passages from one section of the cave to another, ignoring natural tunnels.

The shooter is the main supplier of all damage in the team. It has no disadvantages in combat: huge damage is combined with the largest ammunition among all classes. In case of danger, it has a shield, under the dome of which you and your allies are practically invulnerable. But the shooter has great difficulty moving: the rope allows the whole team to overcome huge depressions and high ledges, but their number is very limited.

The engineer in DRG, unlike in many games, is not a slave to his turret â€“ it is just another tool here. The engineer is a versatile fighter. You have a shotgun against single targets, and a grenade launcher against bugged crowds. The turret finishes off everyone who managed to survive under your fire or crept up unnoticed. For mobility, you have a platform cannon that creates platforms from which you can build bridges, onto which you can fall so as not to take damage, but use them as footholds for the scout so that he can dig up minerals that are inaccessible to others.

The scout is the most mobile class. Your arsenal includes an unlimited cat hook and a lighting pistol, with which you remove the darkness of the depths and uncover cave treasures. Together with an engineer, you dig up the largest number of resources and are the first to determine the situation in the next segment of the cave. Your weapons are accurate and deal quick damage, which is ideal for killing priority targets, but the fundamental lack of damage in the area and the permanent shortage of ammunition will always be your companions.

Progress in DRG does not last very long. You will upgrade all 4 classes in about 50 hours. For those who have gone into the gameplay quite a lot, it remains only to discover special modifications for weapons and unique cosmetics, but the amount of good received is limited to 10-11 pieces each week.

The DRG community is another strong point of the game. Playing with random numbers rarely causes problems, so don't worry if you don't have any friends â€” you'll get all the same emotions. If you are still not satisfied with the randomness, playing alone (while playing a full-fledged single game, with a pause when entering the menu) is possible in the Bosco company. The game has both text and voice chat for communication, but you won't use them: in practice, a laser pointer (Ctrl) and the V button are enough to convey any thought to your friend. It is worth warning that there is no antiâ€”cheat and reporter system in DRG, and therefore, in case of incidents, the best thing you can do is immediately log out of the unscrupulous player's server.

A classic co-op horde shooter that is up there with the greats like L4D, Alien Swarm, and Payday 2.

Over 5 years of free content updates means there's lots of variety to keep things fresh, and they're still continuing to add more. They've done a good job of managing power creep and complexity over those updates, so even if you're jumping in fresh you can have fun with the initially unlocked weapons and not feel overwhelmed by all the mechanics. Although there are a lot of different objectives and events, you can probably figure them out on the fly if you pay attention to what mission control says. And they actually have an in-game "miner manual" that covers the enemies and objectives, so you don't need to rely on a third-party wiki or youtube videos if you want to study the basics before diving in. I wish more games would do this!

Because of the relatively flat complexity, it's a good game to play with friends of differing experience/skill levels. Even if you don't have a friend group who plays regularly, I mostly play with randoms and have found the community well above average in terms of friendliness. The assignments (basically a sequence of target missions that you get an award for completing all of) also help organize random players into the same lobbies, so even when the game is going through a quiet period you can usually find someone running the same target mission to join. Just don't deposit a gold nugget without annoying mission control first, or there may be hell to pay.

There are numerous different unlock trees (weapons, weapon mods, weapon skins and colors, dwarf perks, dwarf outfits, beers!) that are deep and uniquely integrated into the game so you can always be progressing multiple things and always unlocking something new to experiment with. As someone who needs extrinsic goals like unlockables to help give me direction in large games, these deep trees are a major factor as to why I'm still playing after 600+ hours.

There are 4 dwarf classes, each of which gets its own unique collection of weapons to choose from and have their own support role to play on the team. They each play very differently, and I would recommend cycling through all 4 of them to keep things fresh. The way the mechanics synergize do a good job of encouraging team play even among strangers, so long as they're paying a little attention. But other classes can also work around a missing class (or a newbie who's still learning).

There is a single player mode if you aren't feeling social or want to practice before diving into a team. You get a directable robot buddy that helps you out in lieu of dwarf teammates. He's like a puppy: he can dig, fetch, and fire missiles at horrible abominations.

The game is buy once and play all you want. The gameplay updates have all been free, including their equivalent of seasonal "battlepasses" to unlock even more cosmetics that come with each new content season. You can also play previous seasons to enjoy their unique twists and unlock their cosmetics. There's some paid DLC for extra cosmetic skins that aren't otherwise unlockable, but they are dwarfed by the number of free cosmetics you can unlock just by playing. I like to think of them as opportunities to buy the devs a beer after so many years of playing the game.

Also, the game has a great sense of humor (specifically, dwarf humor) and the devs have clearly spent a lot of time and love adding little trinkets and silly interactions/voicelines all throughout the game.

If you enjoy co-op horde shooters, this is a must-try in my book.

Im genuinely confused as to how they could take the effort to make the base game and then instead of building in a leveling system that gives abundant variety and build depth, they just dont. Its basically the exact same experience every single time, just with a different skin because you cannot have any real build depth or leveling that feels rewarding or interesting in any way at all.
